title: Authors and Citation
text: W. Joel Schneider. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Schneider W (2023). psycheval: psychological evaluation toolkit. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/wjschne/psycheval.
code: @Manual{,   title = {psycheval: A psychological evaluation toolkit},   author = {W. Joel Schneider},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/wjschne/psycheval}, }

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: psycheval package set functions can useful psychological evaluations. accompanies Individual Psychometrics online textbook.

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: can install development version psycheval like :
code: remotes::install_github("wjschne/psycheval")

what: Convert a variable to standard scores
title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: Suppose scaled score 12 (μ = 10, σ = 3) want convert standard score (μ = 100, σ = 15). convert z-score (μ = 0, σ = 1): convert T-score (μ = 50, σ = 10):
code: library(psycheval) x2standard(12, mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3) #> [1] 110 x2standard(12,            mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3,            mu_new = 0, sigma_new = 1) #> [1] 0.67 x2standard(12,            mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3,            mu_new = 50, sigma_new = 10) #> [1] 57

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: Let’s create covariance matrix 5 variables correlate .60. Suppose want create sum first 2 variables sum remaining three variables. covariance matrix summary variables ? First create weight matrix w 5 rows 2 columns consisting entirely zeros. first column represents weight first variable. put ones first two rows first column ones rows 3–5 second column. covariance matrix sums : include original variables covariance matrix, append identity matrix w:

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: Suppose two subtest scores = 12 B = 14. scores scaled score metric (μ = 10, σ = 3). want create composite score standard score metric (μ = 100, σ = 15). subtests B correlated ρ = .6.
code: # Subtest scores x <- c(12, 14)  # Subtest correlation rho <- 0.6  # Subtest correlation matrix R <- matrix(c(1,rho, rho, 1), ncol = 2)  # Compute composite score composite_score(x = x,                  R = R,                 mu_x = 10,                 sigma_x = 3,                 mu_composite = 100,                 sigma_composite = 15) #> [1] 116.8

what: Compute a multivariate confidence interval conditioned on a set of observed scores
title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: Compare multivariate CI univariarte CI:
code: library(readr) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  # Observed scores x_wisc <- c(   vci = 130,   vsi = 120,   fri = 123,   wmi = 116,   psi = 97)  # Reliability coefficients rxx_wisc <- c(   vci = .92,   vsi = .92,   fri = .93,   wmi = .92,   psi = .88)  # Correlation matrix R_wisc <- ("   index vci     vsi     fri     wmi     psi   vci   1.00    0.59    0.59    0.53    0.30   vsi   0.59    1.00    0.62    0.50    0.36   fri   0.59    0.62    1.00    0.53    0.31   wmi   0.53    0.50    0.53    1.00    0.36   psi   0.30    0.36    0.31    0.36    1.00") |>    read_tsv(col_types = cols(     .default = col_double(),     index = col_character())) |>    tibble::column_to_rownames("index") |>   as.matrix() R_wisc #>      vci  vsi  fri  wmi  psi #> vci 1.00 0.59 0.59 0.53 0.30 #> vsi 0.59 1.00 0.62 0.50 0.36 #> fri 0.59 0.62 1.00 0.53 0.31 #> wmi 0.53 0.50 0.53 1.00 0.36 #> psi 0.30 0.36 0.31 0.36 1.00  d_ci <- multivariate_ci(   x = x_wisc,   r_xx = rxx_wisc,   mu = rep(100, 5),   sigma = R_wisc * 225)  d_ci  #>     variable   x r_xx mu_univariate see_univariate mu_multivariate #> vci      vci 130 0.92        127.60          4.069          127.88 #> vsi      vsi 120 0.92        118.40          4.069          119.70 #> fri      fri 123 0.93        121.39          3.827          122.33 #> wmi      wmi 116 0.92        114.72          4.069          115.95 #> psi      psi  97 0.88         97.36          4.874           98.86 #>     see_multivariate upper_univariate lower_univariate upper_multivariate #> vci            3.912            135.6           119.62              135.5 #> vsi            3.897            126.4           110.42              127.3 #> fri            3.685            128.9           113.89              129.6 #> wmi            3.954            122.7           106.74              123.7 #> psi            4.803            106.9            87.81              108.3 #>     lower_multivariate #> vci             120.21 #> vsi             112.07 #> fri             115.11 #> wmi             108.20 #> psi              89.44

title: A psychological evaluation toolkit
text: typical -age peer ability W = 500 .90 probability answering question correctly, probability person ability W = 520 answer question correctly? Flipping previous question, person ability W = 520 .90 probability answering question correctly, probability typical -age peer ability W = 500 answer question correctly? Criteria .9 proficiency also possible. example, typical -age peer ability W = 500 .25 probability answering question correctly, probability person ability W = 520 answer question correctly?

what: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
text: Computes covariances composite scores given covariance matrix weight matrix

title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
code: composite_covariance(Sigma, w, correlation = FALSE)

title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
text: Sigma Covariance matrix w Weight matrix. Must number rows R correlation TRUE, return correlations instead covariances

title: Computes covariances of composite scores given a covariance matrix and a weight matrix — composite_covariance
code: # Create variable names v_names <- c(paste0("A_", 1:3),paste0("B_", 1:3)) v_composites <- c("A", "B")  # Create covariance matrix Sigma <- matrix(0.6, nrow = 6, ncol = 6, dimnames = list(v_names, v_names)) diag(Sigma) <- 1  # Create weight matrix w <- matrix(0, nrow = 6, ncol = 2, dimnames = list(v_names, v_composites)) w[v_names[1:3],"A"] <- 1 w[v_names[4:6],"B"] <- 1 w #>     A B #> A_1 1 0 #> A_2 1 0 #> A_3 1 0 #> B_1 0 1 #> B_2 0 1 #> B_3 0 1 # covariance matrix of weighted sums composite_covariance(Sigma, w) #>     A   B #> A 6.6 5.4 #> B 5.4 6.6

title: Compute composite score — composite_score
text: Compute composite score

title: Compute composite score — composite_score
code: composite_score(   x,   R,   mu_x = 100,   sigma_x = 15,   mu_composite = 100,   sigma_composite = 15,   w = NULL )

title: Compute composite score — composite_score
text: x Vector subtest scores R Subtest score correlation matrix mu_x Vector subtest means sigma_x Vector subtest standard deviations mu_composite Composite mean sigma_composite Composite standard deviation w Vector weights

title: Compute composite score — composite_score
text: composite score

title: Compute composite score — composite_score
code: # Subtest scores x <- c(12, 14) R <- matrix(c(1,.6, .6, 1), nrow = 2) composite_score(x = x,                 R = R,                 mu_x = 10,                sigma_x = 3) #> [1] 116.7705

title: Conditional Covariance — conditional_covariance
text: Conditional Covariance

title: Conditional Covariance — conditional_covariance
code: conditional_covariance(x, sigma, mu = 0)

title: Conditional Covariance — conditional_covariance
text: x named numeric vector predictor scores sigma named covariance matrix predictor outcome variables mu single numeric mean variables named vector means predictor outcome variables

title: Conditional Covariance — conditional_covariance
text: list conditional means covariance matrix mu_conditional - means outcome variables conditioned values predictors vector x. mu_sigma - covariance matrix outcome variables conditioned values predictors vector x. descriptives_conditional - data frame means standard deviations outcome variables conditioned values predictors vector x. x - predictor scores x parameter sigma - unconditional covariance matrix sigma parameter mu - Anamed vector unconditional means

title: Conditional Covariance — conditional_covariance
code: # Named vector of predictor scores x <- c(A = 1)  # Named vector of unconditional means mu <- c(A = 0, B = 0, C = 0)  # Unconditional covariance matrix with row and column names sigma <- matrix(c(1, .5, .5,                   .5, 1, .5,                   .5, .5, 1),                 nrow = 3,                 ncol = 3,                 dimnames = list(names(mu),                                 names(mu)))  # Conditoinal means and covariance matrix conditional_covariance(x = x, sigma = sigma, mu = mu) #> $mu_conditional #>   B   C  #> 0.5 0.5  #>  #> $sigma_conditional #>      B    C #> B 0.75 0.25 #> C 0.25 0.75 #>  #> $descriptives_conditional #>   construct mu_conditional sigma_conditional #> B         B            0.5         0.8660254 #> C         C            0.5         0.8660254 #>  #> $x #> A  #> 1  #>  #> $sigma #>     A   B   C #> A 1.0 0.5 0.5 #> B 0.5 1.0 0.5 #> C 0.5 0.5 1.0 #>  #> $mu #> A B C  #> 0 0 0  #>

title: Difference score statistics — difference_score
text: Difference score statistics

title: Difference score statistics — difference_score
code: difference_score(   x,   y,   r_xx = 0.9,   r_yy = 0.9,   r_xy = 0,   mu = 100,   sigma = 15,   ci = 0.95,   mu_x = mu,   mu_y = mu,   sigma_x = sigma,   sigma_y = sigma,   tails = 2 )

title: Difference score statistics — difference_score
text: x first score y second score r_xx reliability x r_yy reliability y r_xy correlation x y mu population mean x y sigma population standard deviation x y ci confidence interval difference score mu_x population mean x (defaults mu) mu_y population mean y (defaults mu) sigma_x population standard deviation x (defaults sigma) sigma_y population standard deviation y (defaults sigma) tails significance prevalence difference scores

title: Difference score statistics — difference_score
text: list

title: Difference score statistics — difference_score

what: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
text: General multivariate confidence interval set scores

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
code: multivariate_ci(x, r_xx, mu, sigma, ci = 0.95, v_names = names(x))

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
text: x vector scores r_xx vector reliability coefficients mu vector means sigma covariance matrix ci confidence level v_names vector names

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
text: data frame following columns: variable - Variable names x - Variable scores r_xx - Reliability coefficients mu_univariate - Expected true score estimated corresponding observed score see_univariate - Standard error estimate computed corresponding reliability coefficient mu_multivariate - Expected true score estimated observed scores see_multivariate - Standard error estimate computed corresponding reliability coefficient upper_univariate - upper bound univariate confidence interval lower_univariate - lower bound univariate confidence interval upper_multivariate - upper bound multivariate confidence interval lower_multivariate - lower bound multivariate confidence interval

title: General a multivariate confidence interval for a set of scores — multivariate_ci
code: # Observed Scores x <- c(   vci = 130,   vsi = 130,   fri = 70,   wmi = 130,   psi = 130 )  # Reliability Coefficients r_xx <- c(   vci = .92,   vsi = .92,   fri = .93,   wmi = .92,   psi = .88   )  # Correlation matrix R <- ("   index  vci   vsi   fri   wmi   psi   vci    1.00  0.59  0.59  0.53  0.30   vsi    0.59  1.00  0.62  0.50  0.36   fri    0.59  0.62  1.00  0.53  0.31   wmi    0.53  0.50  0.53  1.00  0.36   psi    0.30  0.36  0.31  0.36  1.00") |>     readr::read_tsv() |>     tibble::column_to_rownames("index") |>     as.matrix() #> Rows: 5 Columns: 6 #> ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Delimiter: "\t" #> chr (1): index #> dbl (5): vci, vsi, fri, wmi, psi #>  #> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. #> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.   # Covariance matrix  sigma <- R * 15 ^ 2   # Population means#'  mu <- rep(100, 5)   mci <- multivariate_ci(    x = x,    r_xx = r_xx,    mu = mu,    sigma = sigma  )   mci #>     variable   x r_xx mu_univariate see_univariate mu_multivariate #> vci      vci 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       126.69804 #> vsi      vsi 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       126.11601 #> fri      fri  70 0.93          72.1       3.827205        77.64056 #> wmi      wmi 130 0.92         127.6       4.069398       127.29155 #> psi      psi 130 0.88         126.4       4.874423       127.38539 #>     see_multivariate upper_univariate lower_univariate upper_multivariate #> vci         3.911922        135.57587        119.62413          134.36526 #> vsi         3.896561        135.57587        119.62413          133.75313 #> fri         3.685405         79.60118         64.59882           84.86382 #> wmi         3.953840        135.57587        119.62413          135.04093 #> psi         4.803025        135.95369        116.84631          136.79915 #>     lower_multivariate #> vci           119.0308 #> vsi           118.4789 #> fri            70.4173 #> wmi           119.5422 #> psi           117.9716   # Conditional covariance of true score estimates  attr(mci, "conditional_covariance") #>            vci        vsi        fri        wmi        psi #> vci 15.3031321  0.7940793  0.6610628  0.6064452  0.1059996 #> vsi  0.7940793 15.1831840  0.8677571  0.3369836  0.5206229 #> fri  0.6610628  0.8677571 13.5822068  0.5011386  0.1153453 #> wmi  0.6064452  0.3369836  0.5011386 15.6328484  0.5570710 #> psi  0.1059996  0.5206229  0.1153453  0.5570710 23.0690477

what: psycheval: A psychological evaluation toolkit — psycheval-package
title: psycheval: A psychological evaluation toolkit — psycheval-package
text: Functions useful psychological evaluations package accompanies [*Individual Psychometrics*](https://individual-psychometrics.rbind.io/) online textbook.

title: psycheval: A psychological evaluation toolkit — psycheval-package
text: Maintainer: W. Joel Schneider w.joel.schneider@gmail.com (ORCID)

what: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
title: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
text: Convert ability (W scores default) relative proficiency index

title: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
code: rpi(   x,   mu = 500,   scale = 20/log(9),   criterion = 0.9,   reverse = FALSE,   interpretation = FALSE )

title: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
text: x numeric vector ability scores mu numeric vector ability scores reference group scale number vector scaling factor. default value (log(9) / 20) assumes x mu W scores. criterion numeric proficiency criterion (0 1, exclusive) reverse boolean. TRUE, criterion refers proficiency person instead proficiency peer group. words, role x mu reversed. interpretation TRUE, rpi's print method provide interpretation relative proficiency.

title: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
text: numeric

title: Convert ability (in W scores by default) to relative proficiency index — rpi
code: # What is the probability a person with a W score of 540 can pass # an item that a person with a 500 W score can pass with a # probability of .90? rpi(x = 540, mu = 500, criterion = .9) #> 0.9986301 # Same as above but with an interpretive statement rpi(x = 540, mu = 500, criterion = .9, interpretation = TRUE) #> When a same-age peer of average ability has a .90 probability of answering an item correctly, this person has a .999 probability of answering it correctly. # When a person with a W score of 540 has a .9 probability of # passing an item, what is the probability that a person with a W # score of 500 will pass it? rpi(x = 540, mu = 500, criterion = .9, reverse = TRUE, interpretation = TRUE) #> When this person has a .90 probability of answering an item correctly, a same-age peer of average ability has a .10 probability of answering it correctly.

code: w2rpi(w, refw = 500, criterion = 0.9, referse = FALSE, interpretation = FALSE)

title: Convert W scores to relative proficiency index — w2rpi
text: w numeric vector W scores refw numeric vector reference W scores criterion numeric proficiency criterion referse boolean. TRUE, criterion refers proficiency person instead proficiency peer group. words, role w refw reversed. interpretation TRUE, print method provide interpretation relative proficiency.

title: Convert W scores to relative proficiency index — w2rpi
text: numeric

title: Convert W scores to relative proficiency index — w2rpi
code: # What is the probability a person with a W score of 540 can pass # an item that a person with a 500 W score can pass with a # probability of .90? w2rpi(w = 540, refw = 500, criterion = .9) #> [1] 0.9986301 #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "numeric" "rpi"     #> attr(,"p") #> [1] 0.9 #> attr(,"referse") #> [1] FALSE #> attr(,"interpretation") #> [1] FALSE # Same as above but with an interpretive statement w2rpi(w = 540, refw = 500, criterion = .9, interpretation = TRUE) #> [1] 0.9986301 #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "numeric" "rpi"     #> attr(,"p") #> [1] 0.9 #> attr(,"referse") #> [1] FALSE #> attr(,"interpretation") #> [1] TRUE # When a person with a W score of 540 has a .9 probability of # passing an item, what is the probability that a person with a W # score of 500 will pass it? w2rpi(w = 540, refw = 500, criterion = .9, referse = TRUE, interpretation = TRUE) #> [1] 0.1 #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "numeric" "rpi"     #> attr(,"p") #> [1] 0.9 #> attr(,"referse") #> [1] TRUE #> attr(,"interpretation") #> [1] TRUE

what: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
text: Convert x standard score

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
code: x2standard(   x,   mu_x = mean(x, na.rm = T),   sigma_x = stats::sd(x, na.rm = T),   mu_new = 100,   sigma_new = 15,   digits = ifelse(sigma_new == 1, 2, 0) )

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
text: x numeric vector mu_x mean current scores sigma_x standard deviation current scores mu_new mean new scores sigma_new standard deviation new scores digits rounding digits

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
text: numeric vector

title: Convert x to a standard score — x2standard
code: x2standard(13, mu_x = 10, sigma_x = 3) #> [1] 115
